Rainfall data is useful for crop rotation planning, erosion studies as well as useful weather knowledge for predetermined terrains.

Solar insolation data can help us plan locations of solar farms, know if temperatures are too high for growth of certain crops. Scientists can also understand weather and climate patterns with this data.
Ozone\'s impact on climate consists primarily of changes in temperature. The more ozone in a given parcel of air, the more heat it retains.
Increasing water vapor leads to warmer temperatures, which causes more water vapor to be absorbed into the air. Water vapor is known to be Earth’s most abundant greenhouse gas.

Carbon monoxide (CO) is only a very weak direct greenhouse gas, but has important indirect effects on global warming. Carbon monoxide is an ozone precursor, and also reacts with the hydroxyl (OH) radicals in the atmosphere, reducing their abundance.
Sea surface temperatures have a large influence on climate and weather. Even changes of just a few degrees Celsius can influence large-scale weather phenomena, such as El Niño or tropical cyclones.

Temperature is one of the three major influences on global patterns of plant growth. Along with available sunlight and water, temperature determines whether the land will support dense forests, grassland, or nearly barren desert.
Snow cover shows impact of receding coastlines which due to global warming increases the amount of water in the ocean and can lead to flooding and erosion in areas closer to oceons.
Night Lights shows you the distribution of electricity during the Night hours in different locations. Over time, you can tell electricity distribution and consumption has improved in localities.

Vegetation - they feed us, clothe us, absorb carbon dioxide, provide us with oxygen, and give us building materials and medications. When drastic changes occur to the vegetation around us, our health, economy, and environment are all affected.

Accurate topographic data will be used for engineering, energy exploration, conserving natural resources, environmental management, public works design, firefighting, recreation, geology and city planning, to name just a few areas.

Fire is a recurring part of nature. Wildfires can be caused by lightning striking a forest canopy or, in a few isolated cases, by lava or hot rocks ejected from erupting volcanoes. Most fires worldwide are started by humans, sometimes accidentally and sometimes on purpose. Not all fires are bad. Fire clears away dead and dying underbrush, which can help restore forest ecosystems to good health.
Demographic data is effective for studies relating to land use, Rural-Urban Mapping projects, Natural Resource Management Index and global poverty distribution maps.

This map shows where tiny, floating plants live in the ocean. These plants, called phytoplankton, are an important part of the ocean\'s food chain because many animals (such as small fish and whales) feed on them. Scientists can learn a lot about the ocean by observing where and when phytoplankton grow in large numbers.
